attributes.alt: Book cover for Twenty Yawns by Pulitzer Prize winner Jane Smiley and Caldecott Honor artist Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a child tucked into bed with her play animals: a bear, a giraffe, a crocodile, a mother kangaroo and her baby, and a horse.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build math background, play a counting game, and introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What is one thing Lucy does during the day?
Read interactively for meaning and enjoyment, pausing to practice counting.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Have children search the room for a specific number of objects or an object with a specific number of parts.
Guide children to describe the object using complete sentences.
What do we do during the day and at night?
What book did you choose? What is this book about?
What does it look like when someone yawns? Can you show me?
Write about something you do at night, but not during the day.
What materials did you use? Why did you choose those? How did you use them?
What sounds do you hear in the word
? Can you write or trace those letters?
What can you build using only three blocks?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Twenty Yawns by Pulitzer Prize winner Jane Smiley and Caldecott Honor artist Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a child tucked into bed with her play animals: a bear, a giraffe, a crocodile, a mother kangaroo and her baby, and a horse.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Start Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice how the characters use memory and to review counting.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Count a certain number of Connecting Cubes and then place them “behind the curtain.”
Guide children to remember how many cubes were counted, and count the same amount.
What do we do during the day and at night?
What book did you choose? Does it take place during the day or at night?
Show what it feels like to be outside on a sunny day.
What changes happen when day turns into night?
Write about playing outside on a sunny day.
Can you draw, paint, or sculpt something you might see on a sunny day?
Look at all of these letters! Do you remember what sounds they all make?
Can you pretend to build a sandcastle using blocks? How many blocks will you use?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Twenty Yawns by Pulitzer Prize winner Jane Smiley and Caldecott Honor artist Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a child tucked into bed with her play animals: a bear, a giraffe, a crocodile, a mother kangaroo and her baby, and a horse.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share a time measurement strategy, play a time game, and introduce vocabulary
Why does Lucy bring her stuffed animals  to bed?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review the passing of time.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Make connections between words and real life.
Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Have children determine whether an activity takes a long time or short time.
Guide children to discuss their reasoning using complete sentences.
What do we do during the day and at night?
What parts of the story happen during the day? At night? How do you know?
Pretend you’re cooking in the kitchen at night. Is it different than during the day? Why?
Can you draw the moon in the night sky? How does it look?
How is a walk outside different at night than during the day?
Can you draw, paint, or sculpt  something you use at night?
What sounds do you hear in the word
Why is it easier to build outside during the day than at night?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Twenty Yawns by Jane Smiley, illustrated by Lauren Castillo .Text copyright © 2016 by Jane Smiley. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Lauren Castillo. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Amazon Publishing.

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Daytime Nighttime. On the left side is the word Daytime written on the sun. Below it are pictures that say: It's daytime in the mountains; It's daytime in the country; It's daytime in the city. On the right  side of the chart is the word Nighttime written over a starry sky. Below it are pictures that say: It's nighttime in the mountains; It's nighttime in the country; It's nighttime in the city.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  Daytime/Nighttime

attributes.alt: Book cover for Twenty Yawns by Pulitzer Prize winner Jane Smiley and Caldecott Honor artist Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a child tucked into bed with her play animals: a bear, a giraffe, a crocodile, a mother kangaroo and her baby, and a horse.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to discuss day and night, play a time game, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question:
What do we do during the day and at night?
Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Guide children to differentiate between day and night.
Guide children to identify activities that occur during the day and at night.
What do we do during the day and at night?
What do you think about that book? What was the best part?
How would you act differently if you were doing the same thing at night?
Which of these groups has more?
What will you write first? Why are you planning to write about that?
Can you draw, paint, or sculpt something you see at night? How would you compare it to something you see during the day?
What sounds do you hear in the word
? Can you write some of those letters?
Can you build something special that you would only use at night?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Twenty Yawns by Pulitzer Prize winner Jane Smiley and Caldecott Honor artist Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a child tucked into bed with her play animals: a bear, a giraffe, a crocodile, a mother kangaroo and her baby, and a horse.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect to language and discuss day and night, engage children with movement, and play a counting game.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What is your favorite thing to do during the day?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and to review measurement.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Support children as they independently respond to the prompt:
Which do you like more: day or night? Why?
Save children’s writing for display next week.
What do we do during the day and at night?
What kind of book do you want to read next?
Pretend that you are going on a nighttime adventure. What should you wear? What should you bring?
Use Pattern Blocks to create the sun in the sky.
Can you write about which you like more, day or night, and why?
Think about what your home looks like at night and draw a picture of it.
with  these letters? What sounds do you hear?
Count out 10 blocks. Can you use just these blocks to build one short building and one tall building? Let’s see!
